'''Air India Express Flight 812''' was a scheduled passenger service from [[Dubai]] to [[Mangalore]], which, at around 06:30 [[Indian Standard Time|IST]] on 22 May 2010,<ref name="AI Media Release 1">{{cite web
 | url=http://www.airindia.in/SBCMS/Webpages/2010-ai-express-ix-812-accident5.aspx
 | title = Air India Express IX-812 Accident – Press Release 5 
 | publisher=[[Air India]] | accessdate  =22 May 2010| date = 22 May 2010
 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.airindia.in%2FSBCMS%2FWebpages%2F2010-ai-express-ix-812-accident5.aspx&date=2012-03-17
 | archivedate=17 March 2012
}}</ref><ref name="150 killed as Air India plane crashes in Mangalore"/> overshot the runway on landing, fell over a cliff, and caught fire, spreading wreckage across the surrounding hillside.<ref name="150 killed as Air India plane crashes in Mangalore">{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/150-killed-as-Air-India-plane-crashes-in-Mangalore/Article1-546915.aspx|title=Plane crash in Mangalore kills 158, eight survive|date=22 May 2010|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|location=India|accessdate=22 May 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hindustantimes.com%2FIndia-news%2FNewDelhi%2F150-killed-as-Air-India-plane-crashes-in-Mangalore%2FArticle1-546915.aspx&date=2012-02-15|archivedate=15 February 2012}}</ref><ref name="cliff">{{cite news
|url =http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/37286182/
|title =India plane crash kills scores; 8 survive
|date =22 May 2010
|accessdate =11 June 2010
|publisher=[[MSNBC]]
|archiveurl =https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftoday.msnbc.msn.com%2Fid%2F37286182%2F&date=2012-02-19
|archivedate =19 February 2012}}</ref><ref name="India plane 'crashes on landing'">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/10141297.stm|title=India plane crash in Mangalore leaves nearly 160 dead|date=22 May 2010|publisher=''[[BBC News]]'' |accessdate=22 May 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.bbc.co.uk%2F2%2Fhi%2Fworld%2F10141297.stm&date=2012-02-19|archivedate=19 February 2012}}</ref> Of the 160 passengers and six crew members on board, only eight passengers survived.<ref name="AI Media Release 6" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.daijiworld.com/news/news_disp.asp?n_id=77862&n_tit=Mangalore+:+The+Lucky+8+who+Survived |title=Mangalore: The Lucky 8 who Survived... |publisher=[[Daijiworld Media]] |date=23 May 2010 |accessdate=10 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.daijiworld.com%2Fnews%2Fnews_disp.asp%3Fn_id%3D77862%26n_tit%3DMangalore%2B%3A%2BThe%2BLucky%2B8%2Bwho%2BSurvived&date=2012-03-01 |archivedate=1 March 2012}}</ref><ref name="airindiasurvlist"/><ref name=aix812pax>{{cite web|url=http://www.airindiaexpress.in/FreeREZ/ADS_WEB/TA/images/list_of_passengers.pdf |title=List of passengers on board IX-812 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=11 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.airindiaexpress.in%2FFreeREZ%2FADS_WEB%2FTA%2Fimages%2Flist_of_passengers.pdf&date=2012-03-17 |archivedate=17 March 2012}}</ref>

With its 158 fatalities, the accident was the [[List of accidents and disasters by death toll#Aviation|third deadliest]] aviation disaster in India, after the [[1996 Charkhi Dadri mid-air collision]], which killed 349, and the 1978 crash of [[Air India Flight 855]], which killed 213.<ref name="India Plane Crash Kills At Least 160 People">{{cite news|author=Bonnett, Tom|url=http://news.sky.com/home/world-news/article/15636434|title=India Plane Overshoots Runway: 158 Dead|date=22 May 2010|publisher=''[[Sky News]]''|accessdate=22 May 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.sky.com%2Fhome%2Fworld-news%2Farticle%2F15636434&date=2012-03-01|archivedate=1 March 2012}}</ref> It marked the first major Indian aviation accident since the July 2000 crash of [[Alliance Air Flight 7412]] in [[Patna]].<ref name="India plane 'crashes on landing'"/> The accident is the deadliest crash of a 737 aircraft (all series) and the eighth hull loss of a {{Nowrap|Boeing 737-800}} aircraft.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/dblist.php?sorteer=datekey&cat=%1&field=typecode&var=103%&lang=&page=2 |title=ASN Aviation Safety Database results |publisher=Aviation Safety Network |date=8 May 2011|accessdate=11 April 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Faviation-safety.net%2Fdatabase%2Fdblist.php%3Fsorteer%3Ddatekey%26cat%3D%251%26field%3Dtypecode%26var%3D103%25%26lang%3D%26page%3D2&date=2012-03-01|archivedate=1 March 2012}}</ref> The crash caused the highest number of aviation fatalities in 2010 and was the second of the year to involve a 737-800.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://arabnews.com/world/article56407.ece|title=Mangalore airport crash is the deadliest air disaster in 2010|date=22 May 2010|accessdate=24 June 2010|work=Arab News|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Farabnews.com%2Fworld%2Farticle56407.ece&date=2012-03-01|archivedate=1 March 2012}}</ref> It was the second time that an aircraft had overshot a runway at Mangalore.

==Aircraft and crew==
The accident involved a [[Boeing 737|Boeing 737-8HG(SFP)]], one of the few 737's with Short Field Performance package to use for landing in airports with short runways, with the [[aircraft registration]] VT–AXV and manufacturer's serial number 36333, line number 2481.<ref name=cnnibn/> The aircraft first flew on 20 December 2007 with the Boeing test registration N1787B and was delivered a month later.<ref name=ASN220510>{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=20100522-0|title=Accident description|date=27 April 2011|publisher=Aviation Safety Network|accessdate=22 May 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Faviation-safety.net%2Fdatabase%2Frecord.php%3Fid%3D20100522-0&date=2012-03-01|archivedate=1 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planespotters.net/Production_List/Boeing/737/36333,VT-AXV-Air-India-Express.php|title=VT-AXV Air India Express Boeing 737-8HG(WL) – cn 36333 / ln 2481|work=Planespotters.net|accessdate=22 May 2010}}</ref> The crew consisted of Captain Zlatko Glušica, First Officer Harbinder Singh Ahluwalia and four flight attendants.<ref name="AI Media Release 1"/><ref name="crew list">{{cite web|url=http://www.airindiaexpress.in/FreeREZ/ADS_WEB/TA/images/ListOfCrew.htm |title=List of Crew |accessdate=22 May 2010 |publisher=[[Air India]] |deadurl=yes [[Jat Airways]] of Serbia), aged 55, a British and Serbian national with over 10,000 hours of flying and over 7,500 hours of command experience, and Ahluwalia (a former employee of [[Jet Airways]] who joined [[Air India Express]] in 2009).<ref name="India Plane Crash Kills At Least 160 People"/><ref name="crew list" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/we-had-no-hope-to-survive-but-we-survived/115929-3.html?from=tn |title=We had no hope of surviving' |author=Staff Writer |publisher=[[CNN-IBN]] |accessdate=22 May March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> Both pilots were based in Mangalore and they were both killed in the crash.<ref name = "cnnibn"/>

==Flight==
The flight departed [[Dubai International Airport]] at 01:06 [[Gulf Standard Time|GST]] (21:06 [[UTC]]).<ref>Final report, section 1.1 "History of Flight", p.1</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://avherald.com/h?article=42bd5e46/0002&opt=0 |title=Crash: Air India Express B738 at Mangalore on 22 May 2010, overran runway on landing |publisher=''The Aviation Herald''|date=26 April 2011 |accessdate=9 February 2012}}</ref> It crashed upon landing at [[Mangalore International Airport]] at 06:05 [[Indian Standard Time|IST]] (00:35 [[UTC]]).<ref>Final report, section 1.1 "History of Flight", p.5</ref> Situated in a hilly area, the airport is one of seven Indian airports designated as a "critical airfield" by the [[Directorate General of Civil Aviation (India)|Directorate General of Civil Aviation]] (DGCA). DGCA rules at critical airfields prohibit "supervised take offs and landings", so that only the captain (not the first officer) may pilot an aircraft during take-off and landing.<ref>{{cite Airport|Lengpui]])<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2010-05-23/news/28485450_1_foreign-pilots-kanu-gohain-safety-norms |title=Indian skies are safe for flying: Kanu |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65yzdJPTm?url=http://www.hindu.com/2010/05/23/stories/2010052356181100.htm |archivedate= 7 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>

==Crash==
[[File:Bajpe plane crash (40).jpg|thumb|The plane's wreckage at the crash site]]

After touching down on the {{convert|8033|ft|m|adj=on}} runway 24, the plane overran and crashed down the hill at its far end.<ref name="India Plane Crash Kills At Least 160 People"/> The final conversations between [[Air traffic control]] (ATC) and the pilot prior to the landing showed no indication of distress.<ref name="India Plane Crash Kills At Least 160 People"/><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/mangalore-atc-had-no-inkling-of-a-disaster/116125-3.html?from=tn |title=Last conversation between ATC and IX 812 – India News – IBNLive |publisher=[[CNN-IBN]] |date=3 February 2010 |accessdate=10 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65yzv6Mlq?url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/mangalore-atc-had-no-inkling-of-a-disaster/116125-3.html?from=tn |archivedate= 7 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>

The then-[[Ministry of Civil Aviation (India)|Civil Aviation Minister]], [[Praful Patel]] said that the aircraft was following an [[Instrument landing system]] (ILS) approach for landing on the newer, longer, runway, which was commissioned in 2006. The pilot reported to ATC that it was 'established' on an ILS approach about {{Convert|4.3|mi|km}} from touchdown; landing clearance was then given at {{convert|2000|ft|m}} from touchdown. The aircraft concluded its ILS approach on runway 24, touching down {{convert|5200|ft|m}} from the start of the runway, leaving {{convert|2800|ft|m}} in which to stop.<ref>Final report, Executive summary, p.(viii)</ref> It overran the runway and ploughed through a {{Convert|90|m|ft|adj=on}} sand arrestor bed which did not stop it. As the aircraft passed the arrestor bed, its starboard wing collided with the concrete socket of the ILS localiser antenna; it finally plunged over the edge of the table-top about {{convert|790|ft|m}} beyond the end of the runway and down the steep hillside coming to a stop {{Convert|660|to|980|ft|m}} metres past the top of the slope.<ref name="cliff"/>{{#tag:ref|TDZ – Touch Down Zone v/s touch down point. By definition, the touchdown ''zone'' normally extends over the first {{convert|3000|ft|m}} of RW and the pilot aims to touch down at a ''point'' that is well within the limits of the zone, typically around the {{convert|1000|ft|m}} mark for a B737. The zone gives leeway to account for variations in physical conditions such as adverse winds, optical illusions due to day/night/rain/sloping terrain, equipment malfunctions, piloting technique etc. One of the demands of a critical airfield is to land accurately, as close as possible, to the planned touch down point.|group=Note}}

"The plane broke in two," said one survivor, "and a dense black smoke invaded the cabin. I jumped out through an opening in the window. Six other passengers followed me. We fled, with the help of the inhabitants of the nearby village".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Mangalore,-survivor-tells-of-air-disaster-18488.html|title=Mangalore, survivor tells of air disaster |publisher=''Asia News'' |date=24 May 2010|first=Nirmala  |last= Carvalho |accessdate=5 August 2010}}</ref> Television footage from shortly after the crash showed the remains of the aircraft on fire and lying on its belly with smoke rising from the wreckage.<ref name="AFP">{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i1dlQDP_pQtNmq9iTHt-___JAyGA |title=More than 60 feared dead after India plane crash |agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] |date=21 May 2010 |accessdate=9 February 2012 |author=Chand, Naseeb |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100525123019/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i1dlQDP_pQtNmq9iTHt-___JAyGA |archivedate=25 May 2010 }}</ref> The minister also stated that weather conditions were normal with a visibility of {{Convert|3.7|mi|km}}, and said wind conditions were calm and there was no rain at the time of the crash. A drizzle started only after the accident.<ref name="India plane 'crashes on landing'"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/todays-paper/article992447.ece?ref=archive |title=158 killed in Mangalore air crash; 8 survive |publisher=''[[The Hindu Business Line]]'' |date=22 May 2010 |accessdate=10 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66A8O9PZd?url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/todays-paper/article992447.ece?ref=archive |archivedate=14 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="cnn search">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/05/23/india.plane.crash/index.html?hpt=T2 |title=Air India's flight data recorder sought |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=24 May 2010 |accessdate=23 May 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66A8WeZfa?url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/05/23/india.plane.crash/index.html?hpt=T2 |archivedate=14 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>

==Victims==
Apart from the six crew members, a total of 160 passengers were on board at the time of the crash.<ref name=ASN220510/> Although there were 169 names on the original passenger list, nine did not board the flight.<ref name=ASN220510/> All the bodies were recovered from the wreckage.<ref name="hindu435516">{{cite web|url=http://beta.thehindu.com/news/national/article435516.ece |title=158 killed as plane crashes at Mangalore |last=Mondal |first=Sudipto |work=[[The Hindu]] |location=India |accessdate=22 May 2010 |date=22 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65a4i8dqX?url=http://beta.thehindu.com/news/national/article435516.ece |archivedate=20 February 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> [[Karnataka]] Home Minister [[V. ==Investigation==
Initial investigations revealed that the plane landed at least {{convert|2000|ft|m}} beyond the usual touch down point on Mangalore's new {{convert|8040|ft|m|adj=on}} runway 24.<ref name = "cnnibn"/><ref name=AH42bd5e46>{{cite web|url=http://avherald.com/h?article=42bd5e46&opt=0 |title=Crash: Air India Express B738 at Mangalore on May 22nd 2010, overran runway at landing |publisher=''The Aviation Herald'' |first=Simon |last=Hradecky |date=3 August 2010|accessdate=22 May 2010}}</ref> A team of airline officials, staff and officials from the [[Airports Authority of India]] and officers of the [[Directorate General of Civil Aviation (India)]] were rushed to the scene to investigate the accident and assist with rescue efforts.<ref name="AI Media Release 1"/> [[Boeing]] also announced that a team would be sent to provide technical assistance following a request from Indian authorities.<ref name="Boeing statement">{{cite web

|accessdate =1 June 2010

Captain Glušica was given clearance to land, however, he suddenly aborted the attempted landing. The aircraft's throttle handle was found in the forward position, suggesting that the pilot had attempted to abort the landing and take off again.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-11772562 |title=Air India plane crash: 'Sleepy' pilot blamed |date=17 November 2010 |accessdate=11 March 2012 |location=London |work=[[BBC News]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/665U8NTMn?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-11772562 |archivedate=11 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> The co-pilot Ahluwalia had warned his commander three times to go around instead of landing; the first of these warnings had come 2.5 miles before the runway threshold.<ref>Final report, section 1.1 "History of Flight", pp.4–5</ref><ref name="co-pilot warning ignored">{{cite news

The enquiry report submitted by the Civil Aviation Ministry said that Glušica slept for over 90 minutes during the flight. The Air India Express IX 812 {{Nowrap|Boeing 737-800}} carrying 166 people from Dubai including the crew, crashed while negotiating a tricky landing at Mangalore city's "table-top" airport overlooking a ravine. The American National Transportation Safety Board says it was the first instance of snoring recorded on a Cockpit Voice Recorder (CVR).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/pilot-error-behind-mangalore-air-crash-report/135177-3.html?from=tn |title=Pilot error behind Mangalore crash: Report |publisher=[[CNN-IBN]] |date=16 November 2010 |accessdate=11 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/662JHBQxm?url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/pilot-error-behind-mangalore-air-crash-report/135177-3.html?from=tn |archivedate= 9 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> Analysis of the accident revealed that had the pilot "deployed détente reverse thrust and applied maximum manual braking at touchdown", the aircraft could have been stopped within the paved overrun area of the runway. near [[Klamath Falls Airport]], [[Klamath Falls, Oregon|Klamath Falls]], [[Oregon]] | Origin = [[Klamath Falls]] | Stopover = [[Rogue Valley International-Medford Airport|Medford Airport]], [[Medford, Oregon|Medford]], [[Oregon]] | Destination = [[Seattle-Tacoma International Airport]], [[Seattle, Washington]] | Fatalities = 4 (all) | Injuries = 0 | Aircraft Type = [[Fokker F-27]] | Operator = [[West Coast Airlines]] | Tail Number = N2712 | Passengers = 1 | Crew = 3 | Survivors = 0 }} '''West Coast Airlines Flight 720''' was a scheduled passenger flight from [[Klamath Falls, Oregon]], to [[Seattle, Washington]], with intermediate stops at [[Medford, Oregon]], [[North Bend, Oregon]], and [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Oregon]]. On March 10, 1967, it crashed shortly after takeoff at Klamath Falls, killing all four aboard. == Synopsis == West Coast Airlines Flight 720 was operated on March 10, 1967 by one of the company's Fokker F-27's, registered N2712. On the morning of the flight, the aircraft was parked in West Coast's hangar at the airport for routine maintenance.[http://www.airdisaster.com/reports/ntsb/AAR68-AD.pdf ]{{dead link|date=January 2018}} Due to the falling snow that morning, instead of loading at the terminal, as was standard procedure, the aircraft was loaded in the hangar with the passenger and crew members. Both pilots did a pre-flight check of the plane, and reported nothing unusual. Once boarding was completed at 4:46 AM, the plane was pushed out of the hangar. Snow mixed with rain was falling. During push back from the hangar, the tractor tug was observed to have gotten stuck in the snow, and ground personnel spent 11 minutes freeing it, during which time the airplane was exposed to the weather. No attempt was made to clear the wings or control surfaces of snow. Once freed from the snow, the aircraft taxied to Runway 14 and was given takeoff clearance at 4:57 AM. The aircraft took off at 5:01 AM, and at 5:02:43 the flight contacted the tower to check if they were on radar. This was the last communication from the aircraft. The controller reported to Flight 720 that they were on radar. The controller witnessed a target on his screen drift to the left of the runway centerline and head towards [[Stukel Mountain]] 6 miles from the airport. At 5:02:49 the flight impacted Stukel Mountain, after failing to get airborne high enough to clear the mountain. == Cause and investigation == At 5:09 AM a report came into the tower that an aircraft had crashed on Stukel Mountain. It was observed that the runway tracks were in heavy snow, and the plane swerved to the left on the runway before becoming airborne. By takeoff, the left gear was 12 feet off the runway. Several witnesses in the vicinity saw the airplane flying low, followed by seeing or hearing a large explosion. All reported snow at the time of the crash.Klamath Falls, OR West Coast Airline Plane Crashes, Mar 1967 http://www3.gendisasters.com/node/3623 The aircraft was equipped with a flight data recorder. Although damaged in the crash, the recording medium was able to be read. The aircraft was reported to have climbed to approximately 1 minute after takeoff. Throughout the flight the aircraft was recorded to have continued a turn to the left of the assigned heading. Shortly before impact the aircraft began a sharp turn to the left, towards the mountain, at heading of 042 degrees. The aircraft was equipped with a [[cockpit voice recorder]], which, although damaged, was able to be read. The crew reported a loss of control before impact, along with a report of not being able to see the mountain. An expletive was uttered right before impact. The aircraft was observed to have been accumulating ice and snow on its control surfaces prior to takeoff and when moved out of the hangar. No action was taken by the crew to have the aircraft deiced, and it was believed by the investigation that this was responsible for the accident.http://www.planecrashinfo.com/1967/1967-20.htm Due to the crew's short turnaround schedule, fatigue was suggested as a contributing factor in the accident. == References == {{reflist}} {{Aviation accidents and incidents in 1967}} [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents in the United States in 1967]] [[Category:1967 in Oregon]] [[Category:Airliner accidents and incidents in Oregon]] [[Category:West Coast Airlines accidents and incidents]] [[Category:Disasters in Oregon]] [[Category:Transportation in Klamath County, Oregon]] [[Category:March 1967 events]]

'''Azerbaijan Airlines Flight 217''' was a scheduled passenger flight between [[Baku]] and [[Aktau]], [[Kazakhstan]] that crashed into the [[Caspian Sea]] at ca. 22:40 on 23 December 2005.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/4557116.stm Azerbaijan plane crash 'kills 23' – BBC]</ref> The flight was operated by an [[Antonov An-140]].

==Crash==
Around five minutes after a night-time departure from [[Baku Airport]] the crew reported a systems failure. Heading over the [[Caspian Sea]] at night without flight instruments made it difficult for the crew to judge their flight parameters. Whilst attempting to return to Baku, the aircraft crashed shortly afterwards on the shore of the Caspian Sea, killing all passengers and crew.<ref>[http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=20051223-0 Azerbaijan Airlines Flight 217 information]</ref><ref>http://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/25/world/europe/plane-crashes-into-caspian-23-are-killed.html</ref>

==Aftermath==
Investigations from the [[Kharkov State Aircraft Manufacturing Company]] have discovered that three independent gyroscopes were not providing stabilised heading and altitude performance information to the crew early in the flight.<ref>Kaminski-Morrow, David. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20121104033423/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/crashed-an-140-had-gyro-failure-203970/ Crashed An-140 had gyro failure]." ''[[Flight International]]''. 10 January 2006. Retrieved on 14 June 2012.</ref>

Following the accident, Azerbaijan Airlines grounded the remaining Antonov An-140's and cancelled any future plans of acquiring more of the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]]-built aircraft.

The '''Maltrata bus crash''' was a road accident on 17 April 2006 near the Mexican town of [[Maltrata]], around 125 kilometers from [[Mexico City]]. At least 57 people were killed including 10 children.

== Overview ==

Mexican pilgrims were being transported from [[Guadalajara, Jalisco|Guadalajara]] to Mexico City after they had attended a religious festival in the Northern city. Their 22-year-old [[bus]] had already been travelling for ten hours when [[police]] say it apparently developed a fault, probably with its brakes. The bus was descending a highway on a steep hill at over 70 miles per hour. The driver attempted to manoeuvre into an emergency [[hard shoulder]] but lost control, sending the bus rolling down a ravine which bordered the road.  

The bus fell approximately 650 feet into the stream bed below, crashing into the hillside several times as it descended. The bus was well over its capacity of 46, carrying at least 60 passengers. 57 of those were killed in the impact, and the three survivors were all very seriously injured. Initial reports said that there had been 71 passengers on the bus and 63 had died, but these numbers were scaled back as bodies were identified and several critically injured people died in the rescue operation.

The police believe that the bus's brakes were faulty, having not been serviced properly in many years, and that the driver was driving much too fast for the dangerous road, which is a well known accident black spot, owing to the lack of [[crash barrier]]s. The owner of the company which supplied the bus was taken in for questioning by Mexican police.

On 4 April 1975,<ref group="Notes" name="DateNote"/> a [[Lockheed C-5A Galaxy]] participating in [[Operation Babylift]] crashed on approach during an emergency landing at [[Tan Son Nhut Air Base]], [[South Vietnam]]. The cause was ascribed to loss of flight control due to explosive decompression and structural failure. The accident marked the second operational loss and first fatal crash for the C-5 Galaxy fleet, and is the deadliest accident involving a U.S. military aircraft.{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}

== Background ==
Early in April 1975 with much of South Vietnam overrun by [[North Vietnam]]ese forces, the administration of US President [[Gerald Ford]] began instituting the evacuation of American citizens. To avoid alarming the host country, U.S. Ambassador to South Vietnam [[Graham Martin]] authorized Americans to be flown out under several conditions, one of which was [[Operation Babylift]], in which American caregivers were paired with South [[Vietnamese people|Vietnamese]] orphans, most of them fathered by American servicemen.<ref>''Nixon, Ford, and the Abandonment of South Vietnam'', J. Edward Lee and Toby Haynsworth, McFarland and Company, {{ISBN|0-7864-1302-6}}, 2002.</ref>

== Description ==
On the afternoon of Friday, 4 April 1975, C-5A, AF Ser. No. 68-0218, making the first flight of Operation Babylift, departed Tan Son Nhut Air Base for [[Clark Air Base]] in the [[Republic of the Philippines|Philippines]]. This first group of orphans would then transfer to charter flights and be welcomed by President Ford upon arriving in the United States at San Diego, California. At 4:15 p.m. the C-5A was over the [[South China Sea]] about {{convert|13|nmi|km}} off [[Vũng Tàu]],<ref name="babylift" /> South Vietnam, flying a heading of 136 degrees and climbing to an altitude of {{convert|23000|ft|sigfig=3|abbr=on}}. At that moment the locks on the rear loading ramp failed, causing the cargo door to open explosively. This caused [[explosive decompression]], temporarily filling the cabin with a whirlwind of fog and debris. The blowout severed control cables to the tail, causing two of four hydraulic systems to fail, including those for the rudder and elevator,<ref name="LastFlight"/> and leaving the flight control with only the use of one [[aileron]], [[Spoiler (aeronautics)|spoilers]], and power.

The pilot, [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]] Dennis "Bud" Traynor, and copilot, Captain Tilford Harp, attempted to regain control of the airplane, and to perform a 180 degree turn in order to return to Tan Son Nhut.<ref>[http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/1991/August%201991/0891valor.aspx Valor: A Galaxy of Heroes], Air Force Magazine, August 1991.</ref> The aircraft began to exhibit [[phugoid]] oscillations, but the crew countered them and maintained a controlled descent of about {{convert|250|to|260|kn|km/h|lk=in}}. They were able to bring the plane to {{convert|4000|ft|sigfig=3|abbr=on}} and begin the approach to Tan Son Nhut's runway 25L. While turning on final approach, the plane's descent rate suddenly began to increase rapidly.  The crew increased power to the engines in an attempt to arrest the descent, but despite their efforts, the plane touched down at 4:45 p.m. in a rice paddy, and skidded for a quarter of a mile (400 m), became airborne again for another half-mile (800 m), crossing the [[Saigon River]], then hit a dike and broke up into four pieces. The fuel caught fire and some of the wreckage was set ablaze.

Survivors struggled to extricate themselves from the wreckage. The crash site was in a muddy rice paddy near the Saigon River, one mile (1.6 km) from the nearest road. Fire engines could not reach the site, and helicopters had to set down some distance from the wreckage. About 100 South Vietnamese soldiers deployed around the site, which was near the site of an engagement with the [[Viet Cong]] the previous night. Out of 328 people on board, the death toll included 78 children, 35 [[Military Assistance Command, Vietnam#Defence Attaché Office|Defence Attaché Office]] employees and 11 U.S. Air Force personnel; there were 173 survivors.<ref name="LastFlight">{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TmSApdkHyWIC|page=29|title=Last Flight From Saigon|publisher=Diane Publishing|isbn=1-4289-8211-6|volume=IV|journal=USAF Southeast Asia Monograph Series}}</ref> All of the surviving orphans were eventually flown to the United States. The dead orphans were cremated and were interred at the cemetery of the St. Nikolaus Catholic Church in [[Pattaya]], Thailand.<ref name="babylift">Commander in Chief Pacific Command History: Appendix III: Babylift, Carl O. Clever, CINCPAC Hawaii, 1976.  The Vietnam Center and Archive, Item 2132501008, accessed 28 March 2010.</ref> The accident would also "stand as the single largest loss of life" in the [[Defense Intelligence Agency]]'s history until the [[September 11 attacks]] because among the crash fatalities were five female DIA employees.<ref>{{citation|title=THE VIETNAM CAULDRON: Defense Intelligence in the War for Southeast Asia|first=Michael B.|last=Petersen|url=http://www.dia.mil/Portals/27/Documents/About/History/Number%202%20The%20Vietnam%20Cauldron.pdf|series=Defense Intelligence Historical Perspectives, Number 2|year=2012|publisher=Defense Intelligence Agency: Historical Research Division|pages=34–35}}.</ref>

=== Aftermath ===
Some members of the [[United States Congress]] called for a grounding of C-5s. In the end, the fleet was put under severe operational restrictions for several months while the cause was established. The U.S. Air Force Accident Investigation Board attributed the survival of any on board to Captain Traynor{{'}}s unorthodox use of power and his decision to crash-land while the aircraft allowed some control. Captains Traynor and Harp, who both survived, were awarded the [[Air Force Cross (United States)|Air Force Cross]] for extraordinary valor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipient.php?recipientid=3484|title=Dennis W Traynor Air Force Cross|publisher=Military Times Hall of Valor}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipient.php?recipientid=3452|title=Tilford W Harp Air Force Cross|publisher=Military Times Hall of Valor}}</ref> Thirty-seven medals were awarded to crew members or their next of kin. USAF Flight Nurse, 1st Lieutenant Regina Aune, received the [[Cheney Award]] for 1975.<ref>http://www.af.mil/News/Article-Display/Article/109577/two-af-nurses-heroes-of-operation-babylift/</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.af.mil/information/heritage/person.asp?dec=&pid=123006467 |title=Colonel Regina Aune |publisher=US Air Force |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090912041251/http://www.af.mil/information/heritage/person.asp?dec=&pid=123006467 |archivedate=12 September 2009 |df= }}</ref>

==Investigation==
[[File:ILA 2008 PD 061.JPG|thumb|right|Rear doors of a C5 Galaxy]]
Given the explosive manner in which the rear doors failed, sabotage was initially suspected.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.super70s.com/Super70s/Tech/Aviation/Disasters/75-04-04(C5Vietnam).asp|title=C5 Crashes in Vietnam During Operation Babylift|author=Patrick Mondout}}</ref>

Many of the components were looted from the crash site, thereby complicating the investigation; the U.S. Air Force paid a bounty for parts from the wreckage to recover them from the local populace. The [[United States Navy]] [[amphibious cargo ship]] {{USS|Durham|LKA-114}}, [[frigate]] {{USS|Reasoner|FF-1063}}, and [[command ship]] {{USS|Blue Ridge|LCC-19}} were assigned to search for the flight data recorder in the South China Sea.<ref name="babylift" /> The recorder was found, and U.S. Navy ships and helicopters also discovered wreckage from the doors in the South China Sea as well as the body of a C-5 crewmember.<ref name="babylift" />

When the rear doors were eventually recovered from the sea, investigation determined that some of the locks had not engaged properly. Maintenance records showed that locks had been cannibalized for spares, then subsequently improperly refitted so that not all the door locks were engaging correctly. Furthermore, the flight crew confirmed that they had encountered difficulty closing the doors before take-off. As the air pressure differential increased with altitude, the few locks that were working correctly were unable to bear the load, and the door failed.<ref>[https://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19750404-0 Lockheed C-5A Galaxy Accident description] Aviation Safety Network 16 September 2017</ref>

There were no reported injuries to occupants and no reported damage to either aircraft.| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070622191719/http://ntsb.gov/ntsb/brief.asp?ev_id=20070610X00701&key=1| archivedate= June 22, 2007 | deadurl= yes}} [[Federal Aviation Administration|Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)]] officials described the [[runway incursion]] as the most serious incident of its kind in at least a decade, and the [[National Transportation Safety Board|National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB)]] initiated an investigation into the incident.{{Cite news|title=NTSB Investigating runway incursion at San Francisco |work=LARAnews.net |author=LARAnews.net Editorial Team |date=June 11, 2007 |accessdate=July 13, 2007 |url=http://www.laranews.net/?a=1&id=6423 |quote=The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating a runway incursion in San Francisco two weeks ago.}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/pressrel/2007/070611.htm |title=NTSB Advisory |accessdate=July 14, 2007 |date=June 11, 2007 |publisher=[[National Transportation Safety Board]] |quote=The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating a runway incursion in San Francisco two weeks ago in which two airliners may have come within 50 feet of each other on intersecting runways.| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070622191652/http://ntsb.gov/Pressrel/2007/070611.htm| archivedate= June 22, 2007 | deadurl= yes}} ==Incident== [[File:2007 San Francisco International Airport runway incursion.png|thumbnail|left|Visual representation of the runway configuration at SFO. The takeoff path of the jet is shown in red, and the landing path of the turboprop is shown in blue.]] The SkyWest aircraft was arriving at SFO after a flight from [[Modesto, California]], and was cleared for a [[visual approach]] to runway 28R by [[TRACON|NorCal approach control]]. After being switched over to the tower [[air traffic controller|controller]], SkyWest was cleared to land on runway 28R. At the same time, the Republic Airlines aircraft, bound for [[Los Angeles]], California was instructed to taxi into position and hold for two minutes before takeoff clearance was also granted on the intersecting runway 1L. As the landing SkyWest aircraft passed the [[Visual runways|runway threshold]] the Republic Airlines aircraft was cleared for takeoff. Local procedures and [[FAA Order 7110.65]] require the [[local controller]] to wait until the landing aircraft has passed through the intersection before clearing an aircraft for takeoff on one of the intersecting runways. Approximately 27 seconds later the [[Airport Movement Area Safety System]] (AMASS) issued an aural warning of an imminent collision, and the [[Air traffic controller|local controller]] instructed the SkyWest aircraft to stop, transmitting, "uh, sky-, skywest uhh fifty seven forty one HOLD HOLD HOLD". The SkyWest aircraft came to a stop in the intersection of runways 1L and 28R, while Republic Airlines flight lifted off and overflew it. The initial FAA tower report estimated the aircraft missed colliding by 300 feet; however the Skywest crew estimated the distance as 30 to 50 feet. ==Investigation== Runway safety has been a priority concern for both the FAA and NTSB.[http://www.faa.gov/runwaysafety/ FAA – Office of Runway Safety – Runway Safety Home] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070713053026/http://www.faa.gov/runwaysafety/ |date=July 13, 2007 }}[http://www.ntsb.gov/recs/letters/2000/a00_66_71.pdf runway incursion] In a March 23, 2007 press conference on runway safety the [[FAA Administrator]] [[Marion Blakey|Marion C. The controller had over 20 years' experience.{{Cite news | url = http://www.paloaltodailynews.com/article/2007-6-24-sfo-air-traffic | title = Adrenaline keeps air traffic controllers flying high on the job | work = Palo Alto Daily News | accessdate = July 14, 2007 | author = Abramson, Mark | date = June 24, 2007 | publisher = Daily News Group | quote = In the wake of a near-miss at San Francisco International Airport last month due to an error by an air traffic controller with two decades of experience, several local controllers shared their experiences in the field with the Daily News. |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070703001824/http://www.paloaltodailynews.com/article/2007-6-24-sfo-air-traffic |archivedate = July 3, 2007}} ==SFO and AMASS== {{Main|Airport Movement Area Safety System}} SFO was initially selected for the first test installation of the AMASS ground radar system in 1992. AMASS, which can detect and alert controllers to potential runway conflicts, was intended by the FAA to be eventually installed in 40 airports around the country. However much criticism was directed at the project for cost overruns and lengthy delays.{{Cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/TECH/computing/9908/16/faacrash.idg/index.html | work=CNN | title=FAA's runway safety system off track | date=August 13, 1999 | accessdate=April 22, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100529193338/http://www.cnn.com/TECH/computing/9908/16/faacrash.idg/index.html| archivedate= May 29, 2010 | deadurl= no}} The SFO AMASS was finally declared operational on June 18, 2001.[http://www.ntsb.gov/Speeches/carmody/cc010626.htm Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, House of Representatives] According to AMASS technical support personnel, in a scenario such as this conflict, AMASS is designed to provide an alert 15 seconds before the aircraft reach the conflict point, and the system performed as designed. However, the NTSB has noted that while AMASS alerted in this incident, it did not alert in time to prevent the runway incursion.{{cite web |url=https://app.ntsb.gov/news/events/2007/most_wanted_progress/presentations/runways.html |title=MOST WANTED TRANSPORTATION SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS: Federal Issues, AVIATION, Improve Runway Safety |publisher=[[National Transportation Safety Board]] |accessdate=February 8, 2016}} {{As of|2016|February}}, the NTSB continues to list the 2007 SFO runway incursion as evidence that AMASS is insufficient to prevent runway incursions, and as a result, to list a requirement for positive ground movement control on the board's "Most Wanted Transportation Safety Improvements" list. ==See also== {{Wikinews|NTSB releases updates on status of 3 major US investigations}} * [[Runway incursion]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Aviation accidents and incidents in 2007}} {{DEFAULTSORT:San Francisco International Airport Runway Incursion}} [[Category:Runway incursions]] [[Category:South San Francisco, California]] [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents in the United States in 2007|San Francisco International Airport runway incursion]] [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents caused by air traffic controller error]] [[Category:Airliner accidents and incidents in California]] [[Category:2007 in California]] [[Category:May 2007 events]]
